title.text: Overview of NLP-TEA 2016 Shared Task for Chinese Grammatical Error Diagnosis

abstractContent.text: This paper presents the NLP-TEA 2016 shared task for Chinese grammatical error diagnosis which seeks to identify grammatical error types and their range of occurrence within sentences written by learners of Chinese as foreign language.
We describe the task definition, data preparation , performance metrics, and evaluation results.
Of the 15 teams registered for this shared task, 9 teams developed the system and submitted a total of 36 runs.
We expected this evaluation campaign could lead to the development of more advanced NLP techniques for educational applications, especially for Chinese error detection.
All data sets with gold standards and scoring scripts are made publicly available to researchers.

introductionContent.text: Recently, automated grammar checking for learners of English as a foreign language has attracted more attention.
For example, Helping Our Own (HOO) is a series of shared tasks in correcting textual errors ().
The shared tasks at CoNLL 2013 and CoNLL 2014 focused on grammatical error correction, increasing the visibility of educational application research in the NLP community ().

Many of these learning technologies focus on learners of English as a Foreign Language (EFL), while relatively few grammar checking applications have been developed to support Chinese as a Foreign Language(CFL) learners.

entities.text: Chinese as a Foreign Language(CFL) learners

introductionContent.text: Those applications which do exist rely on a range of techniques, such as statistical learning, rule-based analysis () and hybrid methods ( . In response to the limited availability of CFL learner data for machine learning and linguistic analysis, the ICCE-2014 workshop on Natural Language Processing Techniques for Educational Applications (NLP-TEA) organized a shared task on diagnosing grammatical errors for CFL ( . A second version of this shared task in NLP-TEA was collocated with the ACL-IJCNLP-2015 (.
In conjunction with the COLLING 2016, the third NLP-TEA features a shared task for Chinese grammatical error diagnosis again.

The main purpose of these shared tasks is to provide a common setting so that researchers who approach the tasks using different linguistic factors and computational techniques can compare their results.
Such technical evaluations allow researchers to exchange their experiences to advance the field and eventually develop optimal solutions to this shared task.
The rest of this paper is organized as follows.
Section 2 describes the task in detail.
Section 5 reports the results of the participants' approaches.
Conclusions are finally drawn in Section 6.

datasetContent.text: The learner corpora used in our shared task were taken from two sources: the writing section of the computer-based Test Of Chinese as a Foreign Language (TOCFL) () and the writing section of the Hanyu Shuiping Kaoshi(HSK, Test of Chinese Level)().

datasetContent.text: Native Chinese speakers were trained to manually annotate grammatical errors and provide corrections corresponding to each error.
The data were then split into two mutually exclusive sets as follows.
(1) Training Set: All sentences in this set were used to train the grammatical error diagnostic systems.
Each sentence with annotated grammatical errors and their corresponding corrections is represented in SGML format, as shown in.
For the TOCFL track, we provide 10,693 training sentences with a total of 24,492 grammatical errors, categorized as redundant (4,472 instances), missing, word selection (9,897) and word ordering.

For the HSK track, we provide 10,071 training sentences with a total of 24,797 grammatical errors, categorized as redundant (5,538 instances), missing (6,623), word selection (10,949) and word ordering.
In addition to the data sets provided, participating research teams were allowed to use other public data for system development and implementation.
Use of other data should be specified in the final system report.
